learning_outcomes.description: Analyse the structure, composition and processing‑induced physical, biochemical and chemical changes of grains, legumes, fruits and vegetables, plus critically evaluate the key technological principles used to handle, store and process these foods.

Explain the structure and composition of meat, milk, poultry and seafood, describing the physical, biochemical and chemical changes that occur during their processing, while discussing the main technologies used to handle, store and process these foods.
Analyse how production principles of plant- and animal-based food commodities influence their food processing applications.
Explain the scientific basis of quality problems specific to animal- and plant-based commodities and their derived products.
Work as part of a team to research, collate and critically interpret information relating to next-generation food commodities, and present it in oral form.

assessments.weighting: <dd>15% Each Quiz contributes 7.5% to the overall weighting of 15% </dd>
assessments.task_description:
Overview

You will complete two invigilated In‑class Online Quizzes designed to help you practise the styles of questions you will encounter in the in‑semester exam and end-of-semester exam.


Quiz 1 – Grains

Content focus: Grains – Part 1 and Part 2, delivered in Weeks 2 & 3

When: During the scheduled tutorial in Teaching Week 4

Where: Online via the FOOD2000 Learn.UQ Ultra site accessed on your own electronic device

Duration: 20 minutes

Marks: 20 marks

Attempts: One attempt only

Question types: Multiple choice, true/false, short answer and critical thinking/problem-solving

Weighting: 7.5% of your final grade


Quiz 2 – Fruits & Vegetables

Content focus: Fruits & Vegetables – Part 1 and Part 2, delivered in Weeks 4 & 5

When: During the scheduled tutorial in Teaching Week 4

Where: Online via the FOOD2000 Learn.UQ Ultra site accessed on your own electronic device

Duration: 20 minutes

Marks: 20 marks

Attempts: One attempt only

Question types: Multiple choice, true/false, short answer and critical thinking/problem-solving 

Weighting: 7.5% of your final grade


Students are responsible for ensuring a stable internet connection while undertaking an online test/quiz. This test will be taken on a UQ campus location with secure internet service.

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the online test/quiz: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Seek assistance from the Course Coordinator during this in-class assessment first. Contact AskUs support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The online assessment is completed in the FOOD2000 Learn.UQ Ultra site under the appropriate assessment title.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment examines students’ knowledge and understanding of content delivered in lectures and tutorials during Teaching Weeks 1 to 6.

It will consist of multiple-choice, short answer and essay questions.

The exam will be an on-campus exam, at a scheduled on-campus session. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams. Students must attend the exam in-person.

This St Lucia in-semester exam is centrally scheduled, and will be held at one of the following session dates:

  • Friday 27 March, Saturday 28 March and Sunday 29 March
  • Friday 17 April, Saturday 18 April and Sunday 19 April
  • Saturday 2 May 

The times for the exam may be:

  • Fridays: 5:00pm or 7:15pm
  • Saturday and Sundays: between 8:00am and 7:15pm
  • The first exam of the weekend will commence at 8:00am, and the final session will begin at 7:15pm.

Please refer to the Academic Calendar for possible dates. Students will be advised of specific date, via their exam timetable.

Saturday exams information here: Exam timetables and venues - my.UQ - University of Queensland

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Sequential FOOD2000 Mini-Conference - Next-Gen Foods Symposium (Group Presentation on Next-Gen Foods)
assessments.weighting: <dd>25% Each assessment task is weighted as follows: 8% for pdf of Presentation Slide & 12% of Oral Presentation. 5% for Peer Assessment. </dd>
assessments.due_date:
Presentation Slide pdf due (8% of 20% total weighting) 22/05/2026 2:00 pm

Oral Presentation (12% of 20% total weighting) 26/05/2026 4:00 pm

A pdf version of the group's single PowerPoint slide is to be submitted via the designated link in the Assessment folder on the FOOD2000 Learn.UQ Ultra site.

Oral presentations will be delivered during the Next-Gen Foods Symposium, held in the Lecture and Tutorial class times.
assessments.task_description:
Overview:

This is a group work-based task, where each group will comprise of four students (self-allocated using the FOOD2000 Learn.UQ Ultra site). The groups must be finalised by the end of Teaching Week 9. If a student is unable to find or form a group, the Course Coordinator will assign them to a group by the end of Teaching Week 10.

As part of the FOOD2000 “Mini-Conference/Symposium” held in Teaching Week 13 over afternoon tea, each group will deliver a five-minute oral presentation supported by one PowerPoint slide. All group members must contribute by speaking during the presentation. This activity aims to deepen your understanding of emerging food technologies and their potential impact on the food industry.


Purpose:

  • To critically explore Next-Generation Foods (e.g., cell-cultured meats, precision fermentation proteins, plant-based analogues, hybrid products).
  • To evaluate advantages and disadvantages of these innovations from scientific, technological, sustainability, and ethical perspectives.


Presentation Requirements:

  • Duration: 5 minutes per group.
  • Slide Limit: ONE slide only (A single, well-structured visual).
  • Format: Presented during the Week 13 Symposium (at the Lecture and Tutorial venues).
  • Attendance: All group members are required to attend and participate in the presentation. If a student is unable to present on the scheduled date due to extenuating circumstances, and 50% of the group agrees to requesting - and is granted - a group extension, the group may deliver the presentation in a later week. In this case, the presentation will be made to the Course Coordinator and Guest Lecturer, Dr Davor Daniloski, at a time that suits everyone.
  • Submission of Slides: The presentation slides are required to be uploaded 4 days prior to the scheduled Mini-Conference/Symposium.


Assessment Mark Breakdown:  

  • Group Presentation: 20%
  • Slide Design, Slide Content and Use of Target Language & Referencing will be marked prior to the Oral Group Presentation. This will account for 8% of the 20% total weighting
  • Quality of Delivery, Evidence of Understanding and Answering Questions will be marked on the day of the Next-Gen Foods Symposium. This will account for 12% of the 20% total weighting.


  • Peer Assessment: 5%
  • Students evaluate the contributions of their group members.


Detailed Guidelines for this assessment task will be provided by Dr Davor Daniloski in Teaching Week 9. The Marking Criteria will also be available in Teaching Week 9 on the FOOD2000 Learn.UQ Ultra site.


This oral assessment performance (20% weighting) will be recorded and retained as per UQ Assessment Procedure.


This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. 


A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 


To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools. 


The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately during the presentation. Please see assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.submission_guidelines: A pdf version of the group's single PowerPoint slide must be submitted by the group representative via the Turnitin Link in the Assessment Folder on the FOOD2000 Learn.UQ Ultra site by Friday 22 May at 14:00.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:

The exam will be an on-campus exam, at a scheduled on-campus session.

Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams. Students must attend the exam in-person.

Content assessed will be drawn from the lectures delivered in Teaching Weeks 7 to 12.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 12(23 Feb - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

The lectures will be delivered to cover the various plant-based and animal-based commodities, describing the multiple stages relating to the raw and processed foods in each group. How agricultural and animal processing practices can affect the quality parameters for these commodities will also be discussed.

Teaching Week 1 will introduce students to the discipline of Food Science.

Teaching Weeks 2 to 6 will cover the structure, composition and physicochemical properties of plant-based food commodities, including fruits and vegetables, grains and legumes.

Teaching weeks 7 to 11 will focus on the physicochemical properties of animal-based, protein rich food commodities, including red meats, poultry and eggs, seafood and dairy.

Teaching week 12 will explore the concept of ultra-processed foods.


Sub-activity: Dr Deirdre Mikkelsen will be your lecturer in Weeks 1–3, 6, and 10–12. During these classes, she’ll introduce you to the world of Food Science, with a closer look at key food commodities such as grains, legumes, meat, seafood, poultry, and eggs. She will also run tutorial activities that explore dietary fibre and the gut microbiota. Throughout the semester, Dr Mikkelsen will supervise the in‑class quizzes, host the FOOD2000 Mini‑Conference – the Next‑Generation Foods Symposium – and lead revision sessions to help you prepare for both the in‑semester and end‑of‑semester exams. Dr Joseph Nastasi will deliver the Fruits and Vegetables lectures in Teaching Weeks 4 and 5. He will also run the accompanying tutorial activity in Week 5. Dr Davor Daniloski will deliver the Dairy and Ultra‑processed/Next‑Gen Foods lectures in Teaching Weeks 7 to 9. He will also introduce the Next‑Gen Food Group Work Oral Presentation and run the follow‑up tutorials to support you in completing this assessment during your scheduled class time.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 12(02 Mar - 24 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

The students will have the opportunity to utilise the theory covered in the lectures as well as expand their knowledge by working through complementary exercises and assignment tasks during the tutorials.

Tutorials held in Teaching Weeks 2 to 5 will allow students to focus on whole grains, and attempt Online Quizzes to prepare them for the in-semester exam.

From Teaching Week 8 onwards, students will work as groups to research, discuss and design a presentation focusing on Next-Gen foods. Each student group will give a 5 minute presentation at the "Mini Conference/Symposium" in Week 13 over afternoon tea.


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04, L05

Each student group will give a 5 minute presentation at the "Mini Conference/Symposium" in Week 13 over afternoon tea.

learning_activities.topic:
FOOD2000 Mini-Conference - Next-Gen Foods Symposium

The FOOD2000 Poster Symposium will be held in Teaching week 13 during the timetabled lecture and tutorial sessions over afternoon tea. Each group is required to present a five‑minute oral presentation on Next‑Generation Foods, supported by a single PowerPoint slide. All group members must contribute by speaking during the presentation.


Learning outcomes: L01, L03, L04
